lexUnit.name: worry.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: feel or cause to feel troubled over actual or potential difficulties.

sentence.text: His son has gone off to London , and he worries that he may lose touch with him .
It tells electorates that there can be continual growth and no one need worry that the cost of environmental security will hit spending power or reduce standards of living .
He spent two sleepless nights worrying that he might end up on a murder charge .

Unlike other insecticides , lindane has a high skin-absorption rate and experts worry that repeated treatments could lead to a build-up of this chemical in the body , with possible toxic side effects like convulsions .
I have friends who worry that I do n't eat well and regularly enough but I suppose it is all a continuation of the habits formed when I was a one-woman farmer .
Many of us who are parents -- especially those of us who are single parents or working mothers -- worry we are not perfect .
All the time Maureen was away she was worrying herself sick about Biggles .
This kind of problem has worried some people interested in animals that gain protection from predators by " mimicry " .
They might be worrying themselves sick , thinking she 'd had an accident .
Daniel patted his wife again and tried to reassure her , although he was worried himself about Billy 's wellbeing .
` Of course I still have a wife , but there 's no need for you to worry your pretty little head about it .
I do n't think we need worry ourselves about little Miss Harker . "
He worries a great deal about the house . "
Of course , just as sociologists and poets worry a lot about their actual influence , journalists may often see themselves as hacks and hackettes .
We worry about sectarian exclusiveness without realising that we have become used to living under siege .
Mr Roh and his alliance of squabbling factions are worried by stories in the newspapers hinting that officials in the government 's security organisations are jockeying for power .
Maud was worried by the lighting , which Sir George turned on -- a dim standard lamp by the fire , a slightly happier lamp , made from a Chinese vase , on the table .
He was worried by the decimation of forests by charcoal burners and persuaded King James I to forbid glass furnaces to be fired with wood in 1615 .
She is also worried by its deliberate use with other drugs .
She 's probably been worrying what family secrets I 'd let out of the bag .
I never , ever worry about my age .
And I should n't worry about suiting .
We do not need to worry about Gioella di Grignano .
The family worried about it in their different ways .
My brothers would n't let me worry about money -- they 'd always see me all right . "
` Do n't worry about Rose , " he said .
He worries at the extent to which known Felix pictures have disappeared in the last 30 years , and can detail those that have gone missing from Brighton , The Oval and a Piccadilly pub .
I worry for him .
She could only think and worry for John .
He said it was n't long and that she worried for nothing and I changed the subject .
If , however , your basic pension is your only source of income , you will not have to worry as the amount you receive is below the income tax threshold .
` You must worry like hell at times . "
The meal was passed in comparative silence , each woman worrying in her own way because of George 's failure to return .
Clients also worry about discussing their troubles in case they may not be allowed treatment .
You get the odd burglary , but you do n't worry about walking around at night .
Now I just worry about whether we 'll still have tubes or not .
I do n't want to invest in anything where every day I have to worry whether my managers are going to leave me . "
But Mr Frankland 's next words showed me that I did not need to worry .
